title: Ronnie O'Sullivan outlines career plan to focus on China and 'play odd few in UK'
text:
Ronnie O’Sullivan is planning on a change to his schedule (Picture: Getty Images)

Ronnie O’Sullivan is planning a dramatic revamp of his playing schedule that would see him play the majority of events in China and only ‘the odd few in the UK.’

The Rocket does not compete in all the tournaments available to him on the World Snooker tour and played in Asia just once last season, winning the Shanghai Masters but skipping four major ranking events in China.

The 43-year-old declared that he is not a fan of the travelling and doesn’t like to be away from home for extended periods of time, but he has now changed his tune and plans to focus on the Chinese events over competitions at home.

‘I’ll probably play more of the China events now because they’re the big events and I really enjoy travelling to the place,’ O’Sullivan told PA.

Advertisement

‘I can’t do it all so as long as I qualify for the China events, 80 per cent of my tournaments are probably there, and I’ll probably play the odd few in the UK.’

The five-time world champion is playing in a UK event this week and narrowly won his first round match at the English Open on Monday, beating Jamie O’Neill 4-3.

O’Sullivan has been a vocal critic of the tournament venue, the K2 Leisure Centre, and the 128-man format, but chose to play in this event as it is not far from his Essex homeland.

‘If I’m up the road great, if it’s a train journey for four or five hours I probably swerve it,’ the Rocket said after his first round win in Crawley. ‘I’ll probably try and swerve Scotland [Scottish Open], I love Glasgow but where they put it, it’s not a great place.

‘That’s why I’m playing more China events next, they have good venues, proper tournaments, over here they’re struggling for cash, I think. Over in China they’ve got much more resources financially, they can put a better event on.

‘I don’t really want to have to go through qualifying, but I suppose I’ll have to if I want to play in quality tournaments.’

O’Sullivan is a big fan of the Shanghai Masters (Picture: Getty Images)

As always, you can never be certain whether the mercurial O’Sullivan will stick to what he is saying or do something entirely different.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Having already skipped the first two Chinese ranking events of the season, Ronnie’s new plan clearly has not kicked into gear yet, although he is playing in the World Open in Yushan later this month, an event he has not attended since 2010 and retained his Shanghai Masters title.

It is still yet to be seen if the Rocket will play in the Triple Crown events this season, with the UK Championship, Masters and World Championship all held in England.

The reigning UK champion declared earlier this year that he was not going to bother, but it would remain a huge shock for him not to enter and he admits that he has not finalised his plans.

‘I really haven’t scheduled what I’m going to play in at the moment. I’ll decide nearer the time,’ continued the world number two.

‘I’d love to play a full schedule but I just couldn’t do it, I’d never be at home and I’d be living out of a suitcase.

‘Sometimes you have to look at the end of it and think “is the prize worth the effort?” For me, it’s not so I choose to play minimum events because it’s something for me to do.’

Advertisement

O’Sullivan returns to Crawley on Wednesday for a second round match at the English Open against Yuan Sijun.
